title: Biodiversity of Ghana
text:
The wildlife of <a href="Ghana">Ghana</a> is composed of its <a href="biodiversity">biodiversity</a> of <a href="flora">flora</a> and <a href="fauna">fauna</a>.
Biodiversity.
Fungi.
Ghana is home to a significant number of <a href="fungi">fungi</a> species including: "<a href="Aspergillus%20flavus">Aspergillus flavus</a>"; "<a href="Athelia%20rolfsii">Athelia rolfsii</a>"; "<a href="Auricularia%20auricula-judae">Auricularia auricula-judae</a>"; "<a href="Curvularia">Curvularia</a>"; "<a href="Fusarium%20oxysporum">Fusarium oxysporum</a>"; <a href="Fusarium%20solani%20f.sp.%20pisi">"Fusarium solani" f.sp. "pisi"</a>; "<a href="Gibberella%20intricans">Gibberella intricans</a>"; "<a href="Gibberella%20stilboides">Gibberella stilboides</a>"; and "<a href="Macrophomina%20phaseolina">Macrophomina phaseolina</a>". The true total number of fungal species occurring in Ghana is in the thousands and given the generally accepted estimate that only about 7 percent of all fungi worldwide have so far been discovered and that the amount of available information is still very small.
Flora.
The <a href="flora">flora</a> of Ghana is diverse with both indigenous and introduced <a href="flora">flora</a>l species considered in Ghana's floral diversity. A total of some 3,600 species of the major regional centres of <a href="endemism">endemism</a> represent the three major <a href="taxonomic%20groups">taxonomic groups</a>. Floral diversity is more pronounced among the <a href="angiosperm">angiosperm</a>s represented with well over 2,974 indigenous and 253 introduced species in Ghana. Among the various vegetation types of the <a href="tropical%20rain%20forest">tropical rain forest</a>, it is the wet <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> forest type in the southwestern <a href="Geography%20of%20Ghana%23Ashanti%20Uplands">Ashanti-Kwahu</a> <a href="Plain">Plain</a> that exhibits the highest level of endemism and species richness in Ghana.
Flora species diversity and <a href="endemism">endemism</a> in the <a href="savanna">savanna</a> <a href="biome">biome</a>s in Ghana is very sparse and <a href="Biology">biological</a> diversity of species in the Ghanaian savanna <a href="woodland">woodland</a>s and <a href="gallery%20forest">gallery forest</a>s of the savannas show greater species richness than the dry savannas. Within Ghana, there are areas of high biological diversity, referred to as prime biological locations; such as the <a href="List%20of%20national%20parks%20of%20Ghana">Ankasa</a> and <a href="List%20of%20national%20parks%20of%20Ghana">Nini-Suhien</a> <a href="Conservation%20Area">Conservation Area</a> in the southwestern Ashanti-Kwahu erea <a href="Plain">terrestrial plain</a> of Ghana, in where the climatic diversity is greater. There are also "<a href="Encephalartos">Encephalartos barteri</a>", and <a href="gymnosperm">gymnosperm</a> indigenous to Ghana; others growing in various Ghanaian <a href="Ecoregion">ecological zones</a> are introduced species for purposes including aesthetics and economic. The third <a href="Taxonomy%20%28biology%29">taxonomic group</a>; <a href="pteridophyte">pteridophyte</a>s, is well represented in Ghana with 124 known species.
Fauna.
Ghana has a vast array of fauna and they are of great significance, as some of Ghana's fauna have attained conservation status because of the current rate of decline in their number and distribution. The fauna of the Ghanaian terrestrial <a href="ecosystem">ecosystem</a>, comprise a diverse array of species including several of conservation concern. Ghanaian records show that there is as many as 221 species of <a href="amphibian">amphibian</a>s and <a href="reptile">reptile</a>s, 724 species of birds, 225 <a href="mammal">mammal</a>ian species inhabiting Ghana; with 93 recorded to be inhabiting the Ghanaian <a href="savanna">savanna</a> ecological zone. As with floral diversity, prime locations for faunal diversity is located in the Ghanaian high forest uplands; accounting for 83% of the total number of butterfly species recorded in Ghana, where <a href="Canopy%20%28biology%29">canopy</a> stratification and <a href="Microclimate">micro-climatic</a> differentiation have provided habitats and niches for specific faunal organisms.
<a href="Endemism">Endemism</a> among Ghanaian terrestrial fauna has been observed in three species of <a href="frog">frog</a>s; "<a href="Hyperolius%20baumanni">Hyperolius baumanni</a>"; "<a href="Hyperolius%20fusciventris">Hyperolius fusciventris</a>"; and "<a href="Hyperolius%20sylvaticus">Hyperolius sylvaticus</a>"; and the <a href="lizard">lizard</a>s; and "<a href="Agama%20%28genus%29">Agama sylvanus</a>" found in the Ghanaian Bia Forest Reserve and the Atwema Range <a href="Forest%20reserve">Forest Reserve</a>. Ghana has a high degree of <a href="butterfly">butterfly</a> endemism where more than 20 species are classified endemic or near-endemic. Ghana is home to 84 known <a href="amphibian">amphibian</a> species: 78 frogs, 5 <a href="toads">toads</a> and <a href="caecilian">caecilian</a>s. Threatened species recorded in Ghana include four species of <a href="marine%20turtle">marine turtle</a>s and three species of <a href="crocodile">crocodile</a>s. Bird species of conservation concern include seven threatened species, including four species endemic to the <a href="Upper%20Guinea">Upper Guinea</a> forest block and seven near-threatened species.
Keystone species such as <a href="hornbill">hornbill</a>s, <a href="parrot">parrot</a>s and <a href="birds%20of%20prey">birds of prey</a> (<a href="eagle">eagle</a>s) are well represented in Ghana. Of the 728 birds species confirmed to be occurring in Ghana; 408 are non-passerines and 320 <a href="passerine">passerine</a>s, of which 498 are known or thought to be resident and 176 are regular seasonal <a href="Bird%20migration">bird migrants</a>, including 100 from the <a href="Palearctic%20realm">Palearctic realm</a>. Of the total number of species occurring; 180 restricted to the Guinea-Congo <a href="forest">forest</a>s <a href="biome">biome</a> and 37 restricted to the Sudan-Guinea <a href="savanna">savanna</a> biome have been recorded in Ghana. Eleven of the 15 endemic bird species within the Upper Guinea forest occur in Ghana. Six of the total species are considered threatened and 12 are near-threatened.
Ghana is an important country for dozens of <a href="Vulnerable%20species">vulnerable</a>, <a href="Threatened%20species">threatened</a>, <a href="Endangered%20species">endangered</a>, <a href="Critically%20Endangered">critically endangered</a> or near-extinct mammalian species including the <a href="primate">primate</a>s <a href="common%20chimpanzee">common chimpanzee</a> ("Pan troglodytes") and <a href="western%20red%20colobus">western red colobus</a> ("Piliocolobus badius"), the <a href="big%20cat">big cat</a>s <a href="lion">lion</a> ("Panthera leo") and <a href="leopard">leopard</a> ("Panthera pardus"), <a href="African%20bush%20elephant">African bush elephant</a> ("Loxodonta africana"), and <a href="Water%20bird">water-birds</a>, being located on the boundary of the east Atlantic Ocean Flyway and Mediterranean Flyway. There are also several rare terrestrial birds, such as the <a href="white-necked%20rockfowl">white-necked rockfowl</a> ("Picathartes gymnocephalus").
